X. Local Involvement

1. Selection of Study Areas

One of the early decisions made by the Mayor’s
Advisory Committee on Small Business was to
select three of the seventeen older shopping
areas for study instead of singling out one or
two. The rationale was twofold:

a. While none of the three areas could be said to
be typical of all older retail centers, the
combination of three diverse areas came as
close as possible, thus fulfilling the
Demonstration Grant requirement for national
applicability.

b. The Light Street, Monument Street and
Pennsylvania Avenue merchants’ associations
were among the most active and most
progressive in the city; hence, there was reason
to expect a high degree of cooperation in the
development and, hopefully, subsequent
implementation of the plans.

Despite their dependence, to varying degrees,
upon the pedestrian shopper, all three areas
were in critical need of parking. Many shoppers
will bypass closer centers to drive to a more
distant center for a variety of reasons. Some
may have moved from the neighborhood but
continue the habit of shopping in familiar
surroundings; some follow a family tradition of
many years; some have built up a personal
relationship with an owner, manager or sales
person; and some are accepted as charge
account customers by neighborhood stores and
cannot or do not avail themselves of the same
privilege in department stores. Each of the
three areas contains a public market which has
an attraction for many shoppers not within
walking distance. And even those within
walking distance often require a car to load
bulky marketing.

During this Demonstration Project, a precedent
was established with the opening of the City's
first neighborhood off-street parking lot in the
Monument Street business area. A lot for the
Light Street area has been approved and should
be operational in the near future. In each case,
the merchants’ association leases the lot from
the City, manages it and returns all revenue
from its use to the City, with a minimum per
dnnum guarantee. It was felt by the

Committee that the leverage provided by

these lots would be helpful in stimulating the
INitiative for future economic development.

2. Light Street and Monument Street
Although the individual characteristics of each
of the subject areas has been discussed
previously in this report, they share in common
the fact that, except for Charles Street, one
block to the west of Light Street, neither has
yet deteriorated to the degree necessary for
meeting urban renewal criteria. The problem
here, as in so many other fairly healthy centers
elsewhere, is that there are no provisions for
dealing with moderate blight and no funds
available for “‘preventive rehabilitation.”

In seeking an answer, the Small Business
Committee met with representatives of the
business areas and members of the city
administration. Three possible courses of action
were discussed:

~a. Spot clearance. While it would successfully

eliminate the blighted sections in or adjacent to
the core, it was felt that the process would be
too costly and too time-consuming in relation
to the benefits gained.

b. Creation of a citywide Development
Corporation. The Corporation would be a
private one, albeit with quasi-governmental
status, working closely with the appropriate
city agencies, particularly Planning and Housing
and Community Development. Its purpose
would be to stimulate and coordinate all
nonresidential economic development in the
city, including industrial and commercial as
well as retail.

Financing for the Development Corporation
could come from the private sector and from
the Small Business Administration’s 502
Program. Small local development companies
organized for specific and limited objectives
could be formed in such areas as Light Street
and Monument Street. The Development
Corporation would provide professional,
technical and, in some cases, financial
assistance. Details of such a plan must be
further refined and objections expressed to it
must be dealt with.

c. Creation of a “’‘Business Improvement
District.”” This appears to have the most
promise of the three alternatives, and is
essentially a "'self-help’’ program. At the
request of a given business area, the city’s
Department of Planning would assign a district

37

planner to work with the merchants, propérty
owners and, if appropriate, the residents. Any
plan presented would require the approval of
property owners who represent a substantial
majority of the total assessed valuation of the
proposed project district. The City would then
be authorized to issue a bond to finance
detailed planning and execution of an approved
project. The City's investment would be
recovered through an ad valorem assessment to
be imposed upon the properties benefiting
from the improvements, so that it would turn
out to be a self-liquidating venture. The

Maryland General Assembly would have to pass

enabling legislation to give Baltimore this
authority.

In order to more effectively implement such a
project, it would be most helpful if present
federal policy providing long-term low-interest
loans for nonresidential rehabilitation in urban
renewal areas were to be amended so as to offer
the same benefits to a designated Business
Improvement District. ‘

.3.. Pennsylvania Avenue

The Pennsylvania Avenue area offers both the
greatest challenge and the greatest opportunity.
During the term of this Demonstration Project,
it was included as part of the Upton, Urban
Renewal Project and was designated in total
within the Model Cities boundaries.

a. Background

From its earliest days, Pennsylvania Avenue was
a business street. |t was the first road linking
this developing area with rural sections to the
northwest and to the State of Pennsylvania,
hence its name. In 1869, the City Council
provided funds for the purchase of the present
site of the Lafayette Market. One may visualize
the scene in those days of nearby farmers
pulling their wagons down Pennsylvania Road
to sell meats and produce to the inhabitants of
this growing residential area. However, as busy
as it was during the latter part of the 19th and
early part of the 20th centuries, it was not until
after World War | that Pennsylvania Avenue
developed a uniqueness of wider significance in
Baltimore.

Just shortly after the turn of the century, many
Black families who previously occupied houses
only on the small alley streets moved into
residences on the main streets. The ‘Avenue’’
